choices.C: The Query Analyzer can plot a CPU utilization graph for remote hosts with a MySQL Enterprise Service Manager's built-in Agent installation.
choices.B: It is possible to filter a Query Analyzer view graph by database and by table.
choices.A: The Query Analyzer graph view range selector can extend to cover the same hour over multiple days.
choices.D: It is possible to export statements included in a graph selection in CSV format.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about displaying and retrieving data with MySQL Enterprise Monitor Query Analyzer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Cold backups are backups that are performed on data while the database is offline and not accessible to users

choices.C: They are good to use if only data structures must be backed up but not log files.
choices.B: They are backups taken from OS copy commands.
choices.A: They are backups taken from snapshots of a running database.
choices.D: They are good to use when many users are online accessing the database.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about cold backups?

discussion.content: answer is A. Its not B because you can use database1 and still insert into another table on another database. The wild card makes it so if you use another database but insert into this table from another database, it won't happen.

comments.content:
those are the filters only : 
REPLICATE_DO_DB = (db_list)
 | REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB = (db_list)
 | REPLICATE_DO_TABLE = (tbl_list)
 | REPLICATE_IGNORE_TABLE = (tbl_list)
 | REPLICATE_WILD_DO_TABLE = (wild_tbl_list)
 | REPLICATE_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE = (wild_tbl_list)
 | REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB = (db_pair_list)
there is no replicate-wild-ignore

With B, you can still replicate. For example, use DB2; insert into DB1.table1 values (1);
Things in DB1 was still inserted in replication because you were using DB2. ignore db just ignores the base database you are in, not the statement.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
For example, if --replicate-ignore-db=nonreplicated is configured on the replica server, the following sequence of statements causes the GRANT statement to be ignored, because the default database nonreplicated is in effect:

questions.question_text:
You have replication configured, which consists of one master and one slave on different hosts with an asynchronous replication channel between them.
Your goal is to decrease the amount of data that is transferred between these two hosts.
It is confirmed that the slave instance does not need to have data from the example database.
Which replication filter contributes to your goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Used for Replication

choices.A: recording the order in which queries are issued
